title: large wildcat spotted cambridgeshire fen tiger returns
story: According to legend, the Fen Tiger has been on the prowl in Cambs and beyond for more than  years, with a number of sightings reported across the county.The latest sighting was recorded near Coldhams Lane, Cambs, on Saturday where the cat was said to be as big as a fully grown Labrador.A resident who lives in the area said he believed it was looking for small animals to eat around his property.He added that the cat had visited in the past, but this time he was able to capture it on camera.He told Cambridgeshire Live: It was around  or .am this morning when I saw the animal from my kitchen window.Initially I thought it was a wildcat like a Felis Silvestris, but then I went to my colleagues at the university and they said it cant have been as this animal was way bigger.The animal was a brown and black colour with a very long tail that had lots of black circles on it. The tail was so long, and its legs were thick as well with big claws.I think it somehow keeps coming to this place to hunt rabbits or other small animals.It was about the size of a fully grown Labrador dog.When asked whether or not the animal could have been the Fen Tiger the man added: I have heard about the mystery of the Fen Tiger but I dont knowthis was it.This was a wild cat like people have said the Fen Tiger is and this one is the size of a Labrador dog.The theory that Britain has an elusive population of wild big cats has proved enduring, with many people reporting sightings in rural areas.Last year, a wildcat expert revealed there had been five confirmed sightings of pumas in the UK, warning a population of around  were breeding across the country.Rick Minter, Britains leading big cat tracker, said he had seen conclusive videos of the animals amid estimates that hundreds have made the UK their home.In August, a photographer claimed to see a dog-sized cat prowling around the Yorkshire countryside.John Pearson, , was taking pictures at St Aidans Nature Reserve near Leeds when the mysterious creature caught his eye.And last April, a Labrador-sized feline was filmed prowling a field near a Cotswolds pub as police and the RSPCA told of a hamlet in Cornwall where pets have vanished is being stalked by a large panther-like animal.Several people claim to have seen the Beast of Ossett which has been spotted prowling in the woodland and fields around the West Yorkshire town.There have also been a number of alleged sightings of the Wildcat of the Wolds near Drfield, East Riding, Yorkshire, where incidents of mutilated livestock were reported as well.Back in , Lee Clford thought he had captured a photograph of a wildcat roaming the countryside near Hull.

title: mum nurse shop aldi boys lockdown
story: A SINGLE mum who works as a nurse was told she couldnt go shopping at Aldi - because she had her seven-year-old twin sons with her.Victoria Astley, , had already spent half-an-hour in a queue for the store in Fenton, Stoke-on-Trent when she was refused entry by a security guard.The officer told her she couldnt go inside because she was with her sons Harvey and Joseph - and the supermarket only allows in one child at a time.Now bosses at the store have apologised to the mum for the upset.Victoria initially took to Facebook to warn other single mums about the new coronavirus lockdown rules.She wrote: Just a word of warning for single mum Aldi shoppers with more than one child.After queuing for half-an-hour with my seven-year-old twin boys, we finally got to the doors when a security guard told me we werent allowed in as its only one adult with one child.I told him that Im a single parents and theres no one at home to watch the kids.Victoria was forced to put one of the twins in a trolley and leave him at the door of the supermarket.She could only shop in areas of the shop where she could see him at all times.In an interview with the Stoke Sentinel, Victoria said: Ive been off work for seven months because Ive got osteoarthritis, fibromyalgia and other chronic health conditions, so I was already feeling a bit off after queuing.We had been to Asda previously and they let us in no problem.Aldi has offered Victoria a £ voucher as a gesture of goodwill.A spokesperson said: To help with social distancing, were encouraging all customers to try to reduce the number of family members they bring with them into our stores.However, where necessary, parents can of course shop with their children and we will remind the security guards at our Fenton store of our policy.Last week, single mum Elena Sotiriou, , who lives in Upminster, Essex, accused Iceland of discriminating against one-parent families after she was told she wasnt allowed to shop with her two young children.

title: breast pumps converted ventilators coronavirus
story: BREAST pumps are being converted into ventilators for coronavirus patients to combat shortages.Engineers in the US came up with the idea of using the machines, which are used to pull milk from a womans breast, into le-saving breathing devices.The team from Maryland have already built a few prototypes and say - with all the parts - it costs about  .Thats compared with about with the ,to ,price tag for a hospital-grade ventilator, according to SILive.Ventilators work by taking over a patients breathingwhile they are sedated, pushing air into the lungs and giving time to fight the infection and recover.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.One of the advantages of using breast pumps is that they’re built to medical standards, and have a closed-loop compressor that avoids getting contaminated as tubing only needs to be replaced between patients.Software engineer Rachel Labatt told WMAR news she came up with the idea after the US Food and Drug Administration approved the emergency use of medical devices, including positive pressure devices.After a conversation with another engineer friend, Brandi Gerstner, they used their old breast pumps to try it out.Brandi took an X-Acto kne and a screwdriver to reverse the pump’s suctionso it expels air, rather than taking it in, reports WBALTV.She even rigged the breathing instrument so that it pumps air in accordance with medical oxygen intake standards.Electrical engineer Alex Scott, who is also part of the project, said that they also soldered on a few pins onto the control board to turn it on and off.The team are working with certied pulmonologists to get the green light from the FDA so they can start putting the retrofitted respirators in hospitals.Before they’re patient-ready, however, the breath pumps will need to be outfitted with a circuit board and emergency sensors to ensure consistent air flow.Not to mention “making sure that their units in their final form are going to be sanitisable,” Brandi told WBALTV.Rachel added: “Our end goal is to get ventilators to hospitals to save patients.Writing on the teams Facebook page, Brandi said: “Safety is our title: beaches parks coronavirus lockdown picnic
story: GREEN spaces, beaches and streets were deserted this weekend as Brits finally took social distancing and stayed indoors this Easter weekend - except for one group of women who were caught enjoying a picnic.The friends sat on the grass in Primrose Hill, North London, this afternoon, but were soon stopped by Camden Council workers.Park benches and outdoor gyms have been taped off across the country by councils in a bid to deter revellers from loitering as parts of the UK saw highs of C on Saturday and Sunday.The colder start today seemed to have put most people off from venturing outside their houses, with a Met Office meteorologist saying it was a shock to the system for some places.On the second weekend of April, cops were called out to over a thousand reports of Covidiots breaking lockdown rules with nearly  house parties across Greater Manchester.Greater Manchester Police received , callouts on Saturday and Sunday including  house parties and  street parties.Police said some house parties had bouncy castles, DJs and fireworks. title: universal credit passport offices
story: Last week DWP boss Therese Coffee said that more than .million fresh claims for support had been made since the coronavirus crisis began.Ministers think up to four million could eventually be lost - putting huge burdens on the welfare bill.One week nearly six million calls to the Univeral Credit helpline were recorded., staff are said to be being redeployed from other areas to help the backlog, and , more people are being hired.An insider at HMPO in Glasgow told the Sunday Mirror that some staff were being given a five-day crash course in training to process them that would normally take six weeks.One said: “I am distraught at the thought of leaving some vulnerable people without anything to live on for possibly weeks at a time when she has very little knowledge of the system.”The DWP and Home Office have been approached for comment.A Government Spokesperson said: “Since the start of the pandemic the whole of Government has looked at ways to support priority work.“Our staff will be fully trained to ensure that they can undertake work on behalf of other government departments effectively so that the most vulnerable in society can access public services as quickly as possible.”Brits no longer need to call Universal Credit as part of the application process - it can be done online and someone will call backneeded.The Department for Work and Pensionsphone lines struggled to cope leaving people on hold for hours, and it eventually resorted to ing calls where people couldnt get through.If you cant apply online, because you have no interest access or a medical condition or disability that means you cant use a computer, you can continue to apply by phone on    in the first instance.Claimants are being urged to let the DWP knowthey have any changes to their situation online via their journal, too.Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced that the basic level of Universal Credit would go up by £ this year to help people struggling with the coronavirus outbreak.Brits are currently banned from visiting any jobcentre in a bid to stop the spread of coronavirus.Benefit reviews and assessments have also been put on hold for three months so staff can instead focus on processing new applications.Universal Credit and benefit debt repayments have also been paused during the coronavirus crisis, although Universal Credit advances still need to be repaid.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk lockdown extended three weeks
story: BRITAIN’s coronavirus lockdown will continue for at least three more weeks with the pandemic peak still days away.Stand-in PM Dominic Raab is set to announce on Thursday that the countrys restrictions will stay in place until at least May .Mr Raab said the UK was “still not past the peak of this virus” as he warned of a “long way to go” in the battle against Covid-.Chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Valance also braced the nation for a “dficult” week of death figures ahead before they expect the fatality rate to begin to slow.But he said that plateau in coronavirus deaths is likely to last for two to three weeks before we see a fall.Mr Raab is set to ask Scotlands First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and leaders from Wales and Northern Ireland to attend a Cobra meeting to ensure there is a UK-wide agreement on the lockdown.But senior ministers are split on whether to encourage some people who cannot work from home toto their places of employment, The Times reports.Some within the government have been shocked at the number of people using Number s furlough scheme which is costing billions and risks severely damaging the UK economy.But others such as Health Secretary Matt Hancock are reportedly against the idea of encouraging people toto work as they believe it would undermine the stay at home message.Yesterday Britains daily death toll fell for the second day with another  passing away from the horric respiratory illness.It came as the number of coronavirus cases worldwide has passed two million, according to a tally from Johns Hopkins University in the US.But scientists have warned that the country will likely endure the peak of the pandemic next week.In the governments press briefing yesterday, Mr Raab confirmed the lockdown would not be lted this week.Evidence suggests Britain is still going through the peak of the virus and the death rate will continue to go up for days to come.Mr Raab said the lockdown had been a success over the Easter bank holiday weekend, despite police having to take action to stop Brits flocking to parks in some areas to soak up the sun.He said: This week SAGEwill review the measures.We will consider their assessment based on the evidence at that point.We dont expect to make any changes.And we wont until we are as confident as we can be that any such changes can be made.He said it was far too early to talk about lting the lockdown and that any suggestion of relaxing the restrictions would be getting ahead of ourselves.SAGE are due to meet this week and look at all the lockdown evidence and how successful its been.But as Britains death numbers continue to rise by greater numbers, there are no plans to lt strict measures until they start to flatten.Mr Raab said: We were concerned that people might start cutting corners or ignoring the advice, in fact the vast majority followed it.At the moment, the evidence suggests we are still going through the peak of this crisis. It is absolutely, crucially important that we don’t take our eye off the ball...We have lost too many loved ones, made too many sacrices to give up now.Chief Scientic Adviser Patrick Vallance said it title: russian schoolgirl 13 pregnant boy 13 baby bump
story: The pregnant -year-old, from the town of Zheleznogorsk,  shocked the world after she appeared on a Russian TV show claiming the father of her child was a youngster named Ivan.But medical expert Dr Evgeny Grekov who examined him said: “There cannot be sperm cells. He is still a child.”The  urology and andrology expert said: “We rechecked the laboratory results three times so there cannot be any mistake.”However the girl has insisted she had no other partner - and she is believed by a psychologist in Russia.Darya posted pictures and a video showing herself  weeks pregnant.She has made clear she is determined to keep the baby, and expects to give birth via Caesarean.She has become a social media star in Russia revealing details and updates about her pregnancy to her thousands of followers.With parental permission, a troubling television show revealed the faces of the children at the centre of a case that has caused deep controversy in Russia.The boy and his parents agreed to his medical examination with the results revealed to millions of viewers when the children, Ivan and Darya, were out of the studio.The kids are said to be from dferent schools in the Krasnoyarsk Territory in Siberia but are understood to have been friends since they were younger.The pregnant girl is planning on keeping the child and has the full support of her family, according to TBK.Cops have launched a probe and the girls school are assisting officers.A police spokesman said: On January , , the police received information from doctors of the Federal State Budget Healthcare Institution of the city of Zheleznogorsk that a -year-old schoolgirl was pregnant.The Investigative Committee of the Russian Federation for the Krasnoyarsk Territory and the Republic of Khakassia have launched an investigation and a decision will follow.Local reports have revealed little about the boy but social media accounts list the pair as married on their profiles.In February, reports from Russian media said Darya claimed she had invented the story about Ivan, and she really became pregnant after she was raped by a -year-old boy named as Stepan.But now taking to her some ,-plus followers on social media she has written: “First of all, I don’t even know any Stepan…”Denying the attack, which was reported to have taken place  in a stairwell, Darya said there were “cameras everywhere”.She has since claimed reports about the  year old boy were “complete nonsense”.She also added there had been no DNA test to establish paternity.Police and the Russian Investigative Committee have not commented on reports that a boy, , was put under house arrest.No charges or criminal investigation have been announced. Darya told her followers: “I’ll tell you more later … why they said that [Ivan] ‘is not fertile’.”She claims to be in a relationship with the ten-year-old, whose mother, Galiana also believes is the father.She said: I understand that he himself maybe doesnt realise what happened.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make title: pensioners happy hour coronavirus
story: A group of  MPs are demanding the Government order firms to create the ‘Happy Hour’ to stave off an epidemic of isolation among over s.Lib Dem MP Jamie Stone, who is spearheading the campaign, said it is vital the elderly are helped to keep in touch with their friends and family during the lockdown.He told The Sun: “Calling elderly family and friends to see how they are is seriously important because, sadly, a lot of people are fearful right now.“Not in any way to underestimate the absolute danger of coronavirus, but all of us have a duty to cheer each other up.With two million pensioners living in poverty and so many more at risk due to this crisis, it is our responsibility as a nation to make sure we’re not isolating this vulnerable population even further.“Happy Hour calls will help older people to stay in touch with their loved ones and avoid loneliness during this global crisis.“Alleviating just this little bit of financial pressure could make all the dference to someone struggling with loneliness right now.”Mr Stone is calling for action after Judith Perham, who lives in his constituency of Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross in Scotland, got in touch with the idea.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealShe said: I know I’m probably one of the lucky ones to be able to use some of - not all of the modern technology - but l also know there are an awful lot of us older generation that don’t.I think that giving some sort of free time on the phone would be of a benefit to them in order to contact family, who might also be experiencing financial hardship at this time and trying to be careful with money.“This is especially important when living in a rural area as we do in the far north of Scotland.We all need to be looking out for each other at this time and,this achieves a result, then l know that with your help we have helped someone somewhere.The letter to Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden urges him to “continue to do all you can to help the most isolated vulnerable people during this health crisis”.Some  MPs, including Lib Dem, Labour and Tory politicians, have signed the letter.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: angela merkel coronavirus lockdown germany
story: ANGELA Merkel is under pressure to reopen schools and factories this week after violence erupted in a backlash at lockdown measures.The Chancellor is set to rule on whether to extend restrictions as the number of coronavirus deaths in the country continued to fall.Germany reported , new confirmed Covid- cases today, marking the third consecutive day of decline, and the  deaths was also the third daily fall.The encouraging stats emerged after reports of thugs attacking police who were enforcing social distancing rules.One group in Frankfurt attacked cops with iron bars when they tried to disperse the crowd.Another group of  attacked an officer with stones and roof tiles and iron bars, Deutsche Welle reported.Germany has weathered the pandemic better than Italy, Spain, France and the UK where the death toll is much higher.But its industrial powerhouse economy is set to take a heavy blow as it is reliant on exports which have fallen drastically.Regional politicians are due to meet Mrs Merkel on Wednesday to discuss a path out of the lockdown, which is in place until at least April .The Chancellor has said the decision will be guided by recommendations from the National Academy of Sciences Leopoldina.It delivered a report today suggesting schools should reopen as soon as possible, starting with primary and middle schools, although it said nurseries should stay closed.Scientists also recommended reopening shops and restaurants as long as social distancing measures are rigorously respected, and for government offices to get back to work.The head of the Academy, Gerald Haug, said this could only happen along with by an obligation to wear face masks on public transport to prevent a second wave of infections.He said: Every citizen should in the future have this type of protection for their mouth and nose and wear it each time social distancing measures cant be respected, he Der Spiegel.Armin Laschet, the conservative governor of North Rhine-Westphalia, called for a responsibleto normalcy.He said small retailers could potentially reopen following the model in place for bakeries with only two customers at a time.Dietmar Woidke, governor of Brandenburg, called for a more cautious approach to avoid the risk of undoing the gains Germany has made in combating the virus.Germanys economy is forecast to shrink by . per cent in the title: dominos staff pictured gloves masks coronavirus lockdown
story: DOMINOS staff have been pictured preparing food without gloves or masks — raising questions about the safety of takeaways during the coronavirus pandemic.Pictures taken on March  also revealed kitchen staff and delivery drivers at stores across the country ignoring social distancing rules, as the firm remains open despite the likes of McDonalds, Pizza Express and KFC closing all stores.They said: The Government have recommended medical masks should be used by healthcare workers and people with symptoms of Covid-.We’ve been advised the best way to reduce risk of infection is to maintain excellent hygiene and strict food handling procedures, but should official guidelines change we will of course, alter our working practices accordingly.The safety of colleagues and customers is Domino’s top priority so we’re working closely with Government and our environmental health authority, who has approved our colleague and customer safety plans.These photos taken the day after lockdown do not show the clear plastic screens our franchisee put in place in early April.We’ve made further major changes such as Contact Free Delivery, stopping our collection service, ending cash handling, simplying the menu, sanitization and improving our already frequent hand washing.It comes as Tyson Fury staged a heavyweight Easter lockdown with his family by ordering in a gut-busting £ pizza delivery.The Gypsy King and his family isolated in style with a mountain of pizza and top-quality nosh.And as the food arrived, Fury joked that the delivery driver — wearing a face mask and gloves — should stand two metres back and leave the food on the doorstep.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britains got talent lift nation
story: One random pull of a playing card and from that five of hearts he was able to predict Simon Cowell was, at that precise moment, subconsciously thinking about “a jetski”. And the moment before that.And probably every spare moment since he was obliged to leave the Sandy Lane Hotel, Barbados, to go through the motions at this old ITV circus, for the th time of asking.Britain’s Got Talent, which began with Ant and Dec sentimentally evoking all the things they love about this great country of ours.The White Clfs of Dover, Blackpool Tower, Edinburgh Castle, Russian sausage dog dancers, a Belgian contortionist, from Got Talent Espana, who scuttled across the stage in the spider position. That sort of quintessentially British thing.There was also, you probably sensed, a collective feeling Britain’s Got Talent didn’t just have a responsibility to lt the nation’s collective mood, over the following  minutes, but a moral duty.An unfair burden to put on any show and a forlorn hope, I thought, given the production has, for many years, involved nothing more inspirational than mixing and matching acts from the worldwide “Talent” franchise with the sort of homegrown sob stories which, however worthy and sincere, can feel a bit beside-the-point compared to the nightmare that’s just engulfed the world.And so it mostly proved on Saturday’s episode.Opinions here will dfer, I realise. In the latter category, though, we had a choir and foster care dancer Yakub, who won me over instantly with his modesty and tact as he announced: “My dream is to dance on . . . I’ve forgotten what I was going to say.” In the former, there was the Belgian contortionist, Papi Flex, an Indian dance troupe and Russia’s Diana Vedyashinka, who has spent the past  years teaching five dachshunds to stand hind-legged on a podium.An admission that made me feel slightly better about spending a similar amount of time watching EastEnders, but not much.There were also, of course, acts that fitted neither category, like James Piper, who’s “a personal trainer by day, magician by night”, meaning he can probably make haemorrhoids appear from nowhere.There was only one person, though, who genuinely lted the gloom.That was the brilliant comedian Steve Royle, from Phoenix Nights and Car Share, whose riotous act, pretending to shove ping-pong balls up his fundament, was funny enough even without the earnest health and safety caption from ITV: “Do not try this at home.” For five glorious minutes I forgot lockdown and began wondering about Steve’s next routine. Then I had to check myself.Because that is the sad and unavoidable issue with these BGT auditions. Unless they’ve got about  weeks of material, coronavirus means it’s a series currently going nowhere.Attempt to press ITV on this matter and all it can tell you is: “We are working with our production colleagues to see how we can make the BGT live shows work in an ever-changing situation.”Mind you, attempt to read Simon Cowell’s mind at the moment and I’m sure you’ll get a far more succinct response.“A jetski.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which month of the year was named after the Roman emperor Augustus Hardball, Ore Oduba: “Which animal has large breeds called Clydesdale and Shire ”Ben Shephard: “On a computer keyboard the abbreviation PGDN is short for page what ”And Ben Shephard: “Gerald Ford served as US President in which decade of the th century ”A BALLSY move, I thought, for ITV to screen a drama comedy about Who Wants To Be A Millionaire’s coughing cheats during the coronavirus outbreak.The dark irony is, though, it was the only show this past week that was good enough to make me forget the ongoing medical crisis for its duration.The second assumption was that Quiz would stand or fall on Michael Sheen’s impression of Tarrant.It doesn’t. And that’s probably just as well, as it’s a slightly hit-and-miss turn. One moment he’s Tarrant, the next he’s Tommy Cooper, but he always looks more like Les Dennis.Luckily for Quiz, however, it barely matters because James Graham’s script sings and Matthew Macfadyen delivers a performance that’s worthy of award nominations playing the thick-as-a-brick Major Charles Ingram. There are issues as well, obviously.Mark Bonnar’s accent sinks somewhere between Stranraer and Larne as Celador boss Paul Smith and there’s an air of ITV self congratulation in the opening hour about Millionaire’s ratings.A dangerous game to play when you’ve now got Secrets Of The Driving Test filling the show’s slot.All is forgiven and forgotten with tonight’s brilliant second instalmentthough, which concentrates on the coughing episode itself and the fallout, as ITV execs try to work out who they should call at Scotland Yard.“It’s the Celebrity Crime Squad.”“Really  It sounds like a s**t detective show.”“It sounds like something we’d make.”Quite.Manny Monthe: “- is a dangerous scoreline because the next goal wins.”Ian Wright: “Pep Guardiola came in and literally cut Joe Hart’s legs off.”Gary Lineker: “Rafa’s comeback in the Champions League final was his finest moment in the Premier League.”IN the continued absence of live sport, the contest of the week was The Great Celebrity Bake Off, on Channel , where two veteran camera-chasers battled it out for screen time and the winner’s apron.A Holly Willoughby on This Morning B Princess Fiona in Shrek The Musical ITV’s hugely entertaining drama Quiz. BBC’s nearly perfect World Cup Rewind series .The quietly brilliant BBC News health correspondent Fergus Walsh and his cameraman Adam Walker deserving awards for their coronavirus reports from UCL Hospital.And the bloke from pest control making a polite exit from Channel ’s The Mum Who Got Tourette’s: “Did Simon tell you I had Tourette’s ”“The thing that gave it away was when you opened the door and called me a c***.”Smug THIS week’s winner is Phillip Schofield and the Mekon from Eagle comic.Sent in by David Thompson, via email. Picture research Amy Reading.But that’s care homes for you, I suppose.Steph McGovern using the phrase “I love it” an average of . times every show.Psychopathic Mexican drug cartels failing to deal with Gordon, Gino and Fred, on their ITV road trip, while they had the chance.And Have I Got News For You ler Ian Hislop claiming: “The Prime Minister’s in hospital, not good for comedy, is it ” ’Cos it wouldn’t be an issuehe A ever bothered cultivating a wider range of targets than just Boris and Trump and B was actually funny.The Steph Show, Jason Manford: “I’ve been watching the show, Steph, and it’s great.”The Steph Show, Steph McGovern: “I set a challenge for Ruth Davidson and Sandi Toksvig to find something in their house that’s a waste of space.”Challenge  That’s no challenge. title: pneumonia vaccine dr hilary questions
story: WE are now in a fourth week of the coronavirus crisis lockdown but many of you are still unsure of how best to protect yourself against the threat.That is why we have teamed up with TV’s Dr Hilary Jones, who has already answered thousands of your questions.Today, Dr Hilary – Health Editor for both ITV’s Good Morning Britain and Lorraine – tells Emma Pietras why it’s no use taking antihistamines to beat the virus and what certain pre-existing conditions can mean for you in the current situation.He also explains why we need to keep respecting social distancing.Q. I have had the pneumonia vaccine. Does that give us any protection against Covid- A. I’m afraid it doesn’t. It specically protects against infection with a nasty bacteria called pneumococcus, which can cause a secondary bacterial chest infection in someone who has a viral pneumonia, but the vaccine does not protect against coronavirus itself.Q. My family and I have been in isolation for  days as I had symptoms. My daughter and I are due to go back to work. If my daughter gets symptoms do we all have to isolate again A. Yes you do. If any of you develop the symptoms of a dry persistent coughor raised temperature the process starts again.Once more testing becomes available to people in your position, we will know whether you need to self-isolate for sure or not. Until then it’s better to be on the safe side.Q. Does taking antihistamines help fight the Covid- infection A. Antihistamines have nothing to offer in the fight against Covid-. They have no antiviral action.Q. Where can I buy the antibody test for Covid- A. Please don’t buy an antibody test for the virus. To my knowledge, there is no accurate, reliable, validated test commercially available, and those that are advertised are at ridiculously inflated prices.Any reliable tests which become available should be reserved for frontline doctors and nurses and their families who may be self-isolating so we can discover which of them are immune and are therefore safe to go back to work with patients.Q. I have a chest infection. Am I more likely to get the virus A. Chest infections cause inflammation within the breathing tubes and lung tissue, which can lower resistance to secondary infections.Viral infections are often complicated by bacterial infections and this would be the only reason why antibiotics might be used.So you should stay at home, avoid visitors and practise physical distancing so you are not exposed to the virus while slightly more vulnerable.Q. My we and I have self-isolated for more than two weeks, as have our two daughters and their families. Nobody shows any symptoms, so why can we not now see each other, respecting social distancing A. We are asking everybody during lock-down to stay at home as much as possible, to avoid public transport, to work from homethey can and only to go out for essential supplies and to physically distance themselves from other people when they do.The more people come into contact with others, the more the virus will spread. If one infected person gives the virus to one fewer person than has previously been happening, the infection rate among the population will fall by  per cent.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Q. Do people living alone need to wash their hands as often or disinfect their home as often as those who live together A. For people who live alone the risk is much lower. You will only be exposed to the virussomeone brings it to your home, such as a visitor or a delivery.So the need to wash your hands is less but you still need to do ityou are handling post, for example, or even stroking your neighbour’s cat or dog.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris nurses back on front line
story: THE two nurses credited by Boris Johnson with saving his le have gone straight back on to the coronavirus front line to help others.Ward sister Jenny McGee, , and staff nurse Luis Pitarma, , became global celebrities after the PM singled them out for praise over the le-saving treatment he received in intensive care at St Thomas’ Hospital, London.And yesterday Jenny’s brother Rob said: “She is very humble and is back at work now for another night sht.“She said she was just really pleased to see all the hard-working people in the NHS be recognised for the amazing work they are doing.“We are all very proud of Jen, not just in the support she gave Boris, but what she has been doing helping everyday people.“While she is blown away by Boris’s recognition, she is just really pleased to see the public recognition for the amazing work the NHS is doing — that made her really proud.”New Zealander Jenny has been in the UK for eight years. She came here to study then took a post at St Thomas’.Mum Caroline described her as an exceptionally friendly person and a dedicated nurse.She said: “It makes us feel exceptionally proud, obviously. But she has told us these things over the years and it doesn’t matter what patient she is looking after, this is what she does.”The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealCaroline said Jenny has described caring for the PM as surreal.She added: “Our daughter’s very professional so we don’t ask things and she doesn’t spill things. So it wasn’t until Boris was out of intensive care that she actually told us.“She said she’d just had the most surreal time in her le and that she had been taking care of Boris — something she’ll never forget.”Dad Mike added: “Over the years she has always told us that her job is one-on-one nursing with very critically ill people and that means she’s there all the time.“So once we’d heard that Boris Johnson had gone into intensive care it was obvious that at some stage Jenny would possibly run into him.“We knew she’d give him the same level of care she’d have given someone  the week before — or will be giving next week. We’re really proud of her.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Portuguese Luis, who moved to London in , is also believed to have gone straight back to work after Mr Johnson was discharged.One of his friends said yesterday: “He’s an amazing guy. This is really special. You just have to treat each patient that comes in and on this occasion it was the Prime Minister.“I think he’s totally gobsmacked by the reaction and the recognition he’s received. To have the Prime Minister praising you for saving his le is incredible.“He really is Luis the lesaver. He is a great guy.” Both Jenny and Luis were hailed as heroes yesterday back in their home countries.Sir Tim Shadbolt, mayor of Jenny’s home city of Invercargill, said: “It’s not very often a nurse from here saves the le of the British Prime Minister.”New Zealand’s prime minister Jacinda Ardern also sent Jenny a Facebook message of thanks. And Jenny’s old school, Verdon College, said it had the “sincerest admiration” for her.It added: “Jenny is described by her past teachers as an absolutely delightful person and someone who had a caring and humble nature.“Thanks Jenny for your courage, outstanding work and the example you have provided for everyone at this dficult time. Your old school community is so proud of you!” Luis, born in Aveiro nearPorto, was congratulated by Portugal’s president Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa during a phone call on Sunday.Mr Johnson paid tribute to the NHS medics who saved him in an emotional video message recorded on Sunday after he was discharged from hospital and reunited with pregnant fiancée Carrie Symonds.He gave a special mention to “Jenny from New Zealand and Luis from Portugal’ — saying they stood at his bedside for  hours when “it could have gone either way”.The PM also name-checked “Po Ling and Shannon and Emily and Angel and Connie and Becky and Rachael and Nicky and Ann”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ben fogle guide explore nature home
story: WITH many of us missing our strolls in the countryside, this nation of nature lovers needs to find a way of keeping in touch with the great outdoors.But just because we are staying safe at home, it doesn’t mean we can’t engage with Britain’s wild side.Adventurer and TV naturalist Ben Fogle is on hand to show you how to encourage ious creatures great and small into your back gardens or on to your window ledges.Ben, , is an ambassador for the World Wide Fund for Nature and is UN Patron Of The Wilderness – which involves highlighting the pressures and impacts on the Earth’s wildest corners.Currently in lockdown with his family, he says: “Evenyou are staying at home it doesn’t mean you can’t explore nature.“This is a chance for the family to get involved with wildle together.“We can be creative and resourceful, using what we have to get the most out of whatever outdoor space we have.”Here, Ben gives GRANT ROLLINGS his guide to how to welcome bugs, birds, amphibians and mammals into your le while stuck at home.IF you don’t have a garden, this will help you to attract wildle to your window ledge.The bug hotel is simple to put together and can be made with objects in your home that Mum and Dad don’t need.For the base you need something substantial, such as old masonry or wood.If you are putting the bug hotel on a windowsill, be careful that there isn’t anything below that it could damage.If the contents are lightweight, use egg containers weighted down with earth. Then build up your hotel with twigs, dry grass, acorns, straw or leaves.Bees, which are in decline across the world, prefer hollow spaces, such as bamboo, to crawl into in winter.Try to place your bug hotel in an area which receives sunlight in the morning and is shaded in the afternoon.Before you know it, spiders, woodlice, ladybirds and all kinds of insects will start arriving.THERE are few joys greater than the sound of birdsong in the morning or the sight of a goldfinch swooping in.And we can all find ways to attract them to our homes, whether it is a large garden or just a window ledge or patio.Many things around the house can be turned into a bird feeder, such as an empty yoghurt pot or the classic half a coconut.Cut holes for string to hang them up.The food can be leftovers, or my children pick out the pips from tomatoes and peppers.Make sure you hang the feeder in a spot which isn’t easily accessed by cats.ONE of the silver linings to the lockdown is that wildle is thriving, with animals venturing into places normally occupied by humans.Hedgehogs have been in steep decline over the past few decades but there are ways to help their numbers rise again.If Mum and Dad use a strimmer around the garden, ask them to be very careful, because these tools can seriously injure these animals as they hide in undergrowth.And our spiny pals in towns and cities have almost been imprisoned because fences between gardens mean they can’t move about.Keeping your two-metre distance, ask your neighbourthey mind you cutting a small, hedgehog-sized shape into the fence.That way you are both creating a hedgehog motorway and bringing neighbours closer together.These wonderful creatures also love a place to hide, so a wood pile is good for them.Just be carefulyou plan to start a bonfire to make sure they are not inside it.One warning, don’t put down milk to feed them. What hedgehogs really like is tinned cat or dog food.A LITTLE water feature will add to the ersity of animals in your garden.It needn’t be a big pond – any container will serve a useful purpose.You could put down a plastic liner or adapt a Tupperware box.Amphibians need a shallow end to access the water, so construct it with dferent depths. One thing is it shouldn’t be so shallow that it dries out in summer. And don’t simply fill it with tap water.You need rain water for it to be desirable to frogs and toads.If you can order plants, there are some which are especially adapted to water, such as the hornwort, which is a great oxygenator.Algae is good food for tadpoles but you need to place the pond partly in the shade.JUST because plant nurseries are closed in the lockdown it doesn’t mean you can’t put flowers in your window box or garden.Many of you will have unused flower seeds in an old drawer or the potting shed and you can still order plants – and herbs, also a good idea – online.Chives, which come back year after year, provide food for both butterflies and bees.Bees are particularly attracted to the colour blue, and geraniums are a good choice, while the herb oregano, an aromatic plant that can be placed on a balcony, will draw in butterflies.If you are growing plants from seed you can plant them in egg boxes with a little soil, and in no time at all you will have created a homemade nursery.It is also helpful to leave a patch of lawn uncut – wildle doesn’t like pristine environments.ANYONE with a garden will be surprised by the amount of nature that already exists there without making any real effort.Before you head out to have a look, get a pen and a paper to note down what you find.Then go out with your children into the nooks and crannies, the deepest undergrowth, and inspect these habitats carefully.It is great to turn over old bricks to look at insects – but while you root around make sure you are not disturbing the homes of larger animals.The kids should note down all the flowers, insects, worms and other creatures they come across.Use your phone to take photos then go online to research what you saw.Find out what trees and plants are in your garden to notice which are good for bees, butterflies or birds.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here. title: couple stunned hot tub office
story: Mark and Jenny Ronsman, from Wisconsin, US, bought their house three-and-a-half years ago and were told about the tub but only recently got around to fixing it.Mark, , said the previous homeowner, an elderly lady, had spoken to them about using the secret tub years ago but had since covered it over due to lack of use.He said: When we bought this house, we knew there was a hot tub in this room.But the elderly woman who sold us the house said they got older and stopped using it, so they converted it to an office.He added that the tub didnt look particularly inviting when the homeowner initially showed them photos.Mark added: She showed us an old photo of it filled with water and people back in the day but it didnt really give you a good feel for how the hot tub looked itself.One of the first things I did when we moved in was tear up that carpet and figure out what was going on.But after digging down into the floor, Mark and Jenny were delighted at what they found.Mark added: I was pleased to find the tile in the hot tub looks beautul! title: judge rinder common furlough questions
story: WHEN it comes to questions about employment during the coronavirus crisis, we are in uncharted legal territory. It’s no wonder so many bosses and workers are confused – lawyers are too!Without statutes in place and with regulations changing, it can be hard to provide a definitive answer. The Government has announced the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme, which means thatyou both agree, your employer can put you on temporary leave .This applies when they are unable to operate or have no work for you to do because of Covid-. If you are furloughed, you will be paid  per cent of your wages by the Government, up to a monthly cap of £,.It sounds straightforward, but your own unique circumstances can make things tricky.  I have been inundated with questions from people who have been furloughed, had their salary cut or lost their jobs.Here, I have provided my answers to some of your most common queries.Q I STARTED a new job shortly before the lock-down. My new company has advised me it cannot pay me the  per cent government pay because I didn’t start before February . What can I do A Annoyingly for you, your new company is almost certainly right. Unless you were on the payroll by February  they are not legally bound to extend the furlough scheme to you. There are talks about this being changed and lots of pressure on the Government because there are a lot of people in your position. In the meantime, you are entitled to Universal Credit — apply now.Q I WAS late getting to work at a food processing plant due to a change in bus timetables caused by the lockdown. My boss said this was a disciplinary offence and fired me. Is this legal A This is probably not legal. If you have been employed for two years or more this counts as unfair dismissal. If you took your employer to an employment tribunal you would have a good chance of winning.  If you haven’t been employed there for  months you would still be entitled to pay for your notice period.  It is possible you could bring a claim for breach of contract as your employer has almost certainly failed to uphold their own disciplinary procedures. You may also be entitled to a claim for discrimination.  Write to this firm making it clear the country is watching their behaviour — as am I.Q I AM on furlough but my employer is holding back a week’s wages I earned before I was furloughed, saying I will get them when my employment starts again. Can he do this  A Your employer cannot do this, unless it was agreed in a contract. You were promised this money and it has absolutely nothing to do with you being furloughed. I have had a number of messages about this unlawful practice and I understand employers are trying to protect cashflow. Butyou were promised this money your firm is not entitled to withhold it.  It may be that, like many others, you will have to work with your employerthey need that money to stay afloat and protect your job, but make sure they put in writing that the money will be forthcoming in due course. Waiting a while for the money may be better than your company going bust.Q AM I entitled to get another job – say, in a supermarket – while I am on furlough from my employer A I have been inundated with people asking this, but the law is not clear. My view is that unless the contract you have with your current employer specically states you cannot take another job , there is no reason why you cannot during this time. There is nothing as it stands in legislation that prevents you from doing this. The government regulationsare not clear and need clarication.  Importantly, disclosure to your current employer is critical. Do not accept another job without giving clear written notice to your current employer that you are taking up other employment while furloughed.Q MY employer wants me to accept a ten per cent pay cut. I checked my contract and I don’t believe they have the power to do this. Do I have a way of resisting this A Your employer cannot unilaterally decide to cut your wages. You have signed a contract and they have promised to pay you. But these are unprecedented times and there is legal provision which may, in certain circumstances, allow employers to sack you and then,necessary, re-employ you on a reduced salary. Multiple employers have asked staff to take a reduction in order for them to survive. The critical thing is thatyou accept such an offer it must have an end date, in writing. You can’t be forced to accept a contract change, including a salary cut. But be warned thatyou do not, your employer can put you on furlough, which will only cover  per cent of your salary.Q I RESIGNED from my job but my new one has fallen through due to the virus. Where can I get help  A I am afraid you will have to claim Universal Credit. It may be worth writing to your old employer to seethere is work still availble, but your legal remedies are limited. The Citizens Advice Bureau is updating its advice on this all the time.Q MY EMPLOYER has gone into administration. Can I still be furloughed A The law makes clear that administrators, independent professionals responsible for either salvaging a bankrupt company or ensuring creditors are paid, can apply to the government furlourgh scheme to ensure an income for staff. However, the administrator will probably focus on attempting to pay creditors and shareholders. Do not let them do this. Get together with co-employees and write to the administrator insisting you’ll not be forgotten and nor will their behaviour.Q I’VE HAD to cancel my holiday and my employer needs me to work during the time I had booked off. Usually we are not entitled to carry annual leave into the next year, butthey are requiring me to work, surely I must have the right to do so A Good news, the Government has amended regulations so workers can carry over up to four weeks holiday into the next two holiday years. This applies where it has not been possible for you to take some or all of your leave because of the virus. However, it has to be because you were required to work.Q I BECAME self-employed in February. Am I entitled to government grants A It looks like you are not, but this may change. You need to have accounts for   to be entitled to assistance. But this situation is moving, so don’t give up hope.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal Q I’M A zero-hours worker. Am I still entitled to be put on furlough  My employer is closed so I have no shts but nothing has been mentioned about furloughing. A The furlough scheme covers zero-hour contract workers so your employer should make an application on your behalf. Get in touch and ask them to explain their policy. It costs them nothing to offer you furlough so I do not understand why they have not.Q I WORK in a shop and my employer has made no effort to make the environment safe for the workers. In other shops I have seen screens at tills and employees issued with gloves and masks. We have none of that. I don’t feel safe. Am I entitled to stop working without risking my job A It is shocking that there are no specic health and safety regulations protecting workers like you which have the full force of law. I do not have a clear answer about whether you are entitled to refuse to go to workthe business is open and offering essential services. However, in due course your business failing to make the environment safe could be grounds for constructive dismissalyou were to make the decision to walk away. I urge you, in the strongest possible terms, to write to your line manager asking them to provide safety equipment, making it clear the environment is unsafe and explaining that you will be considering your optionsadequate safety measures are not introduced.Q I WANT to go on furlough, but my employer has cut my hours by half. How can I make them furlough me so I can get  per cent of my pay instead of  per cent A Your boss can’t just slash your hours by half, that is a straightforward breach of contract. If there is no work for you to do then furlough should be offered to you. Write to your employer at once asking for them to explain why they think this is lawful. I look forward to their answer.Q I CAN’T work because I have to shield myself due to health reasons. I asked my employer to furlough me and they said they couldn’t because I can’t work, so I am currently on unpaid leave. Is this fair A  This all depends on your circumstances. If you are able to work from home, and are healthy enough to do so, your employer should offer you this option. If your employer is unable to operate, or there is no work you could doyou did not have to shield yourself, then you should be offered furlough. Butthe business is an essential service that has remained open, and you have to attend work in person, the remedy is to apply for statutory sick pay .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast britain 20c sunshine icy blast
story: Tuesday and Wednesday will see sunshine and warm weather across the UK with dry weather to follow on Thursday and Friday, with odd showers in the south.While temperatures plummeted on Monday night to as low as -C in parts, this will clear quite quickly and the UK is due to bask in wall-to-wall sunshine on Tuesday.Most areas will see dry weather though parts of eastern, southeastern and central England will start off cloudier before brightening up, whilst the far north of Scotland will be mostly cloudy.Tuesdays temperatures are in line with the average for this time of year, according to Luke Miall, a meteorologist at the Met Office.Only East Anglia is likely to see some cloud cover, although this is not expected to last long.Temperatures are due to rise even higher on Wednesday with the mercury touching between  and C, accompanied by bright, clear skies.News UK has a brand partnership with Switchcraft. It will be more of the same on Thursday and Friday with London and central England seeing temperatures possibly hitting C.Temperatures will be a bit cooler in both northern and eastern parts as well as the far south.Most parts will once again see some fine, bright, sunny weather although south-west England and southern Wales are expected to see some showers. It follows a glorious bank holiday weekend where temperatures soared to record highs, with some Brits flouting lockdown rules and heading to parks and beaches to sunbathe.But Brits were reminded to stay inside and obey the strict government advice despite the warm weather.And just yesterday, Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab warned that the lockdown was unlikely to be lted anytime soon.

title: lion lunges helpless atelope photo
story: Brit photographer Charlie Potter, , caught the pair throwing up spray at high speed on a flood plain in Botswana.The calf managed to evade the big cat — and one of its cubs. Guess they’re not the only ones with nine lives.Charlie, who also plans luxury safaris and works closely with anti-poaching charity ForRangers, said he dubbed the antelope ‘Lucky’ in honour of its escape.He said: “We arrived onto the flood plains just as two fully grown lionesses and roughly six very mature cubs had emerged from the cover of a nearby thicket.“Across the flood plain was a large group of a small antelope called red lechwe.“As the young lions trotted off towards their intended targets, splashing and playing as they went, two adult lionesses sat no more than fteen feet from me in the x.“They watched intently as their offspring stalked the herd and tried their luck at making a kill.“All of the young lions failed miserably except for one who managed to separate this young red lechwe from the main herd and close in on it.“Unfortunately for the lion, the young red lechwe’s speed and agility proved too much, and despite having a paw on its haunches the antelope escaped.”Charlie said any hope of the ordeal being over for the antelope was short lived as it tried to hide in the long grass away from the herd.He said: “It was now split from the rest of its herd with a group of lions separating them.“The young lions more or less lost interest at this point and began to stalk one another, pouncing and play fighting with no real interest in continuing to hunt.“The same was not the case for the two adult lionesses next to me. Having realised their cubs had given up and having maintained an eye on the isolated calf, they decided to show the youngsters how it’s done.“They waited until the clearly tired calf laid down some one-hundred metres away.“Now hidden by the long grass, one lioness slunk around the back of our x as the other crouched low and began moving towards to spot where the small antelope lay.“As she approached, the red lechwe burst from her cover, the lioness in hot pursuit and trying to bend the antelopes run towards her hunting partner.“She did so successfully, and the second lion picked up the chase. Water from the floodplain flew into the air as the chase flew past me.“The antelope calf, with the superior speed and agility in the wet conditions escaped, again. I named her Lucky - not long in the world and having escaped death twice in a single hour.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe government is poised to extend the UKaposs coronavirus lockdown until at least May  in an announcement expected to be made on Thursday. Dominic Raab, who is standing in for Prime Minister Boris Johnson while he recovers from Covid-, will tell Brits that they will have to remain at home for at least another three weeks as ministers grapple with an exit strategy, according to The Times. The lockdown has to be reviewed by law every three weeks, and the first review must be carried out by Thursday this week. The governmentaposs scientic advice group SAGE meets today.But government officials have already made clear there is next to zero chance of restrictions being lted this week. Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey warned today: We’re talking about a battle against coronavirus that isn’t gong to be over in weeks - it will take months.” And Chief Scientic Advisor Sir Patrick Vallance warned Britain must first be firmly on the other side of the peak of new cases and deaths. Daily new cases and deaths are beginning to fall - but it is too early to saythe UK has definitely reached a peak yet, orit is staying on a plateau. For live updates about coronavirus, click HERE. Sir Patrick said: When we are firmly the other side of it in terms of numbers coming down, only at that stage might we look at when those measures might be released. A new poll today shows % of the public favour a cautious approach to lting the lockdown. Public opinion is heavily in favour of preventing the virus spreading, evenit causes economic damage - although % want to get people back to work, evenit means there are more Covid- cases.Cabinet ministers are split over exactly when to end the lockdown - and at what point saving the economy comes before protecting every le. Health Secretary Matt Hancock is said to be anxious to push the stay home and save lives message, and is worried that this could be underminednon-essential businesses are allowed to reopen. There are fears a longer closure of schools will damage the ­prospects of poorer children. But government sources have denied Education Secretary Gavin Williamson is pushing for them to reopen. They told the Mirror: “Schools are closed until further notice and that won’t change until the scientic advice changes.”  Asked when the lockdown might be lted, Cabinet minister Ms Coffey told Sky News the “focus right now” is stopping the spread of the virus and a vaccine “may take some considerable time”. She added: We haven’t hit the peak of the infections and so that’s why it’s important to continue the lockdown measures that we have, which do seem to be working. We will be guided by the modelling done by our scientic and clinical advisors. They are meeting partly today but again later in the week and that will give a fresh opportunity for us to consider what needs to be evaluated in terms of deciding at what point we may need to come out of this. Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and senior figures from the Welsh and Northern Irish governments have reportedly been invited to a COBRA meeting to discuss a UK-wide approach. Government sources admit that ministers are debating how to balance tackling the coronavirus against the economic effect of the lockdown.  One government source told the Mirror : “We’re clearly concerned about the economic impact of all of this but public health is the absolute priority right now. “It would be wrong to look like bean counters at the expense of saving lives.”

title: keir starmer announces investigation leaked
story: NewsKeir Starmer announces investigation into leaked Labour anti-Semitism reportThe document - which claims that Labour staff worked to undermine the Labour leader - will be examined by an independent investigatorShareByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  APR NewsMr Starmer has said the party will appoint someone to investigate the report and its content " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Labouraposs new leadership team have announced an inquiry into a leaked document which alleges that Labour staff conspired to undermine Jeremy Corbynaposs bid to win the  general election and the partyaposs handling of anti-Semitism complaints.Keir Starmer has confirmed an investigation into the -page document, which was drawn up by allies of Mr Corbyn and claims that some senior Labour staff opposed to Mr Corbyn used the partyaposs own machinery to work against the then Labour leader.The internal investigation, leaked widely and seen in full by the Mirror, claims that factional opposition in the upper echelons of the party towards the Islington North MP contributed to a litany of mistakes that hindered the effective handling of anti-semitism. It also claims that party officials opposed to Mr Corbyn worked to lose the  general election in the hope that a bad result would trigger a leadership contest to depose him. In a joint statement, Mr Starmer and his deputy Angela Rayner launched an investigation into the claims made in the document, how the evidence in it was gathered and how it was leaked.  The statement said: “We have seen a copy of an apparently internal report about the work of the Labour Party’s Governance and Legal Unit in relation to antisemitism. The content and the release of the report into the public domain raise a number of matters of serious concern. “We will, therefore, commission an urgent independent investigation into this matter. This investigation will be instructed to look at three areas. First, the background and circumstances in which the report was commissioned and the process involved. Second, the contents and wider culture and practices referred to in the report. Third, the circumstances in which the report was put into the public domain. “We have also asked for immediate sight of any legal advice the Labour Party has already received about the report. “In the meantime, we ask everyone concerned to refrain from drawing conclusions before the investigation is complete and we will be asking the General Secretary to put measures in place to protect the welfare of party members and party staff who are concerned or affected by this report.” The report claims to have found no evidence of anti-Semitism complaints being handled dferently to other forms of complaint, or of current or former staff being motivated by anti-Semitic intent.

Government sources admit that ministers are debating how to balance tackling the coronavirus against the economic effect of the lockdown. One government source said: “We’re clearly concerned about the economic impact of all of this but public health is the absolute priority right now. “It would be wrong to look like bean counters at the expense of saving lives.” But another Cabinet source stressed that the health of the economy and the public’s health were intricately linked. They claimed to the Mirror: “It’s not a binary choice between protecting lives and protecting the economy, we want to protect both.” The source said modelling and analysis were ongoing so officials know what trade-off decisions need to be made. Other elements including the impact of poverty on the public’s health and delays to healthcare for other conditions will also be part of considerations. But the source added: “I don’t see how you can have a conversation about lting lockdown when you are still seeing an increase in the number of deaths.”  There are fears a longer closure of schools will damage the ­prospects of poorer children. But government sources have denied Education Secretary Gavin Williamson is pushing for them to reopen. They told the Mirror: “Schools are closed until further notice and that won’t change until the scientic advice changes.” The government expects to extend the restrictions at a meeting on Thursday, with experts arguing that the UK is not yet through the worst of the pandemic. Tonight First Secretary of State and PM Boris Johnson ’s stand-in Dominic Raab thanked the UK public for staying at home over the Bank Holiday weekend. He said: “People should be in absolutely no doubt that, by staying home this weekend, you have saved lives, and you also helped protect our precious NHS at this critical moment in the crisis.” The coronavirus lockdown is a worrying time for millions across the UK. But itaposs also bringing out the best in people who are selflessly giving their time each day to help those most in need. Our Mirror Coronavirus Heroes series wants to recognise all of those helping the most vulnerable during the crisis. Whether itaposs a local business going the extra mile for the community or a teenager helping an elderly neighbour, we want to hear about it. You can email your stories of Mirror Coronavirus Heroes to webnews@mirror. He added: “We have come too far, lost too many loved ones and sacriced too much to ease up now.” Asked about plans to loosen lockdown restrictions, Mr Raab replied that it was “too early to talk about that”. After another  coronavirus patients died in UK hospital, the total stands at ,. It is the lowest increase recorded over the Bank Holiday weekend, after  on Friday, which surpassed the worst confirmed daily totals in Italy and Spain of  on Saturday and  on Sunday. But experts warned that the lower number was due to the holiday and not necessarily a sign of a slowdown.  Professor James Naismith of the University of Oxford added: “We will have to see further data before making any firm judgment as to trends.” Chief Scientic Officer Sir Patrick Vallance said: “When we are firmly the other side of it in terms of numbers coming down, only at that stage might we look at when those measures might be released.” The Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies will meet today ahead of a decision on Thursday on whether or not to extend the lockdown. Figures show one in seven people who ended up in hospital with coronavirus in the UK have died. As of Sunday , people died with Covid- in NHS hospitals in England out of a total of almost , inpatients. It works out at a death rate of just over % for those who are admitted. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK’s first “virtual parliament” is set to open next week after MPs demanded greater scrutiny of the how the coronavirus crisis is being handled. Ministers refused demands from Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer and other parties to recall Parliament. It will sit from April  as planned, but ministers will be grilled over webcam rather than in person as the battle to stop the spread of the virus continues. The House of Commons Commission will decide how the virtual parliament will work when it meets on Thursday. One option is for Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle to sit alone in the Commons chamber with MPs participating via video link. Ministers would also be required to appear remotely for ministerial question time sessions, urgent questions and other business relating to the House Commons. Another idea is for ministers and shadow ministers to appear in person as other MPs “dial-in”. Sir Keir said: “It’s very important in a crisis like this that Parliament is sitting so that decisions can be properly scrutinised.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWe must not forget the brave NHS workers who have lost their lives to the coronavirus. When the nation needed their dedication, kindness and expertise, they answered that call and, in doing so, paid the highest of prices. These were not just the very best of the health service. They were loved ones, mothers, fathers, sons and daughters. And many of them would be alive todaythey had been provided with the proper kit. For all the wild promises by ministers there is still a woeful shortage of personal protection equipment. Stories from those working in our hospitals, clinics and care homes should shame the Government. Doctors and nurses are putting their lives in danger every day because they do not have enough masks, gowns, gloves and goggles. Faces of the NHS heroes who have died during the coronavirus pandemic Many are having to pay for their own equipment or are having to re-use existing kit. Others have resorted to fashioning make-sht gowns from bin liners. Instead of taking responsibility for this shameful situation, Health Secretary Matt Hancock insinuated that NHS staff were being too profligate in using what he described as “precious” equipment. Essential PPE should not be a luxury that needs rationing. It should be a basic right of anyone working in our health service at this crucial time. This is especially the case when so few frontline workers have been tested so far.  Boris Johnson did not stint in his praise for the NHS workers who saved his le. The National Health Service, the Prime Minister said, is the “best” and the “beating heart of this country.” If Mr Johnson wants to show genuine gratitude these words must be matched by some genuine action. The Prime Minister is rightly recuperating, but the Government must redouble its efforts in his absence.The coronavirus lockdown is a worrying time for millions across the UK. But itaposs also bringing out the best in people who are selflessly giving their time each day to help those most in need. Our Mirror Coronavirus Heroes series wants to recognise all of those helping the most vulnerable during the crisis. Whether itaposs a local business going the extra mile for the community or a teenager helping an elderly neighbour, we want to hear about it. You can email your stories of Mirror Coronavirus Heroes to webnews@mirror. Our political leaders have compared this moment of national crisis to a time of war. If they want to draw comparisons with previous battles then they should act with the same urgency that was shown in previous campaigns. During the Second World War our assembly lines were reconfigured to provide the necessary munitions.  Our industries should be transformed on a similar scale to provide the masks, gowns, goggles and gloves our key workers need. That is why the Mirror is launching our “Protect Us” campaign on behalf of all those serving the country at its time of need. We are demanding PPE is provided for NHS staff, carers, cleaners, porters, transport workers and anyone  who may be at risk. In the First World War the way the heroes in the trenches were let down by the officer class was compared to lions being led by donkeys.In the campaign against the coronavirus our angels on the medical frontline are being commanded by dullards. You should no more consider requesting our NHS staff and carers to tend for the vulnerable without gowns and masks than you would countenance sending soldiers over the top without rles and helmets. Yet that is what is happening now. The heroes and heroines of the NHS are the pride of the country. It is incomprehensible they still do not have the kit they need. And it will be inexcusablemore were to lose their lives because of the incompetence of our political masters.

title: concerts festivals may not return
story: NewsConcerts and festivals like Glastonbury may notuntil Autumn  warns health expertBioethicist and professor of healthcare management Zeke Emanuel has warned that large music events such as Glastonbury and Reading may not be back up and running for more than a yearShareCommentsByMilo Boyd:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsFestival and concerts should not go ahead until Autumn , a health expert has warned " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFestivals and concerts are unlikely to be back up and running until Autumn next year, a healthcare expert has predicted. Chicago based bioethicist and professor of healthcare management Zeke Emanuel has poured cold water on the idea that large public gatherings would be up and running later this year. Speaking at a New York Times roundtable, Mr Emanuel questioned promoters who were rescheduling cancelled events for dates in . “Larger gatherings – conferences, concerts, sporting events – when people say they’re going to reschedule this conference or graduation event for October , I have no idea how they think that’s a plausible possibility, he said. I think those things will be the last to . “Realistically we’re talking fall  at the earliest.” As it stands all UK festivals over the coming months have been cancelled. Glastonbury Festival organisers decided it could not go ahead with its th anniversary in June and BST Hyde Park dates were cancelled. US Festival Coachella moved its festival from April to October this year. Others are playing for time. Reading and Leeds Festival has yet to cancel its outings at the end of August this year, which will see Stomzy, Liam Gallagher and Rage Against the Machine headlinethe events can run. Mr Emanuel added: Restarting the economy has to be done in stages, and it does have to start with more physical distancing at a worksite that allows people who are at lower risk to come back.  “Certain kinds of construction, or manufacturing or offices, in which you can maintain six-foot distances are more reasonable to start sooner.”Yesterday Dominic Raab said the Government will not even consider lting the UK coronavirus lockdown this week. The Foreign Secretary said the UK was still not past the peak of the virus and added that we donapost expect to make any changes to the measures currently in place after scientic advisory groupmeets later this week.
